dc:description: There have been five studies to date that have identified patients with features consistent with Costello syndrome (CS) and de novo or inherited variants in KRAS (Carta et al., 2006; Nava et al., 2007; Schubbert et al., 2007; Zenker et al., 2007). However, none of the patients possessed features to definitively differentiate their diagnosis from other RASopathies as CS. Variable expressivity, age of ascertainment, and outdated clinical assessments of affected individuals may complicate the clinical diagnosis of CS versus severe forms of cardiofaciocutaneous (CFC) syndrome. Therefore, the evidence for this association is Disputed. Furthermore, the HRAS gene is believed to be the only gene associated with CS (Aoki et al., 2005; Estep, Tidyman, Teitell, Cotter, & Rauen, 2006; Gripp et al., 2006; Kerr et al., 2006; Zampino et al., 2007). Of note, KRAS has also been classified as definitive in association with Noonan syndrome (NS) and as strong in association with CFC syndrome. The ClinGen RASopathy Expert Panel found no evidence associating KRAS with NS-like disorder with loose anagen hair or NS with multiple lentigines. This curation was approved by the ClinGen RASopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel on 7/24/18 (SOP Version 5).

evidence.dc:description: There is not enough information to score this variant because it was not found in a de novo case and it was not functionally characterized. Cancer has not been identified in this patient and therefore there is no distinctive Costello feature

evidence.rdfs:label: Bertola 1
evidence.previousTestingDescription: polyhydramnios, ID/Dev delay, failure to thrive, short stature, relative macrocephaly, characteristic facies, cardiac abnormalities, cardiac hypertrophy, hand anomalies, soft/loose skin, curly/sparse hair, papillomata, (no tumor), CNS abnormality, lymphedema.

evidence.dc:description: This patient is described to have overlapping features of Costello syndrome, but the study isn't making the claim that this is a Costello case.

evidence.rdfs:label: Carta 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
"KRAS gene mutation, presented some characteristics of CS,
such as polyhydramnios, failure to thrive, relative macrocephaly,
and suggestive facial features, but lacked the skin
and cardiac anomalies."

evidence.dc:description: This varaint was a de novo variant in a patient who presented with features most consistent with Costello syndrome, however, the clinical diagnosis was based on appearance, heart abnormality, feeding diffuclities and failure to thrive, and none of the features were "admittedly" specific for Costello syndrome, therefore this case should be disputed.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient No 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Pst congenital heart defect, hypertellorism, downslanting palpebral fissures, coarse face, anteverted nostrils, low-set dysplastic ears short stature, macrocephaly, webbed neck, pectus carinatum, ptosis, starbismus, nystagmus, moderate ID, sparse hair, redundant skin, deep palmar and plantar creasees, macroglossia, severe feeding difficulties, and failure to thrive.

evidence.dc:description:
absent from gnomAD
This varaint was a de novo variant in a patient who presented with features most consistent with Costello syndrome, however, the clinical diagnosis was based on appearance, heart abnormality, feeding diffuclities and failure to thrive, and none of the features were "admittedly" specific for Costello syndrome, therefore this case should be disputed.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient No 12
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: hypertelorism, coarse face, anteverted nostrils, low-set dysplastic ears, short stature, relative macrocephaly, short webbed neck, cryptorchidism, ptosis, moderate ID/ dev delay, sparse hair, loose/ redundant and soft skin with deep palmar and plantar creases, Dandy Walker malformation, laryngomalacia, conductive hearing deficits, severe feeding difficulties and failure to thrive.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
14 months- died from unexplained sudden death
KRAS sequencing only?
